Denial of the application for a marriage license was based upon an explicit provision of Halakhah recorded twice in <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:5 and 4:19 and implicit in the ruling of <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 7:17. The Rehovot <i>bet din</i> composed a detailed analysis of the basis of that ruling only because the case was remanded to them on appeal for further consideration by the Supreme Rabbinical Court of Appeals.", "The Gemara, <i>Yevamot</i> 45a, posits a controversy among the <i>Amora\'im</i> regarding the status of the progeny of a union of a non-Jewish man and a Jewish woman. One opinion is that the child born of such a liaison is a <i>mamzer</i> while a second opinion maintains that the child is legitimate but, if a female, is forbidden to marry a priest. The Gemara, <i>Yevamot</i> 45b, concludes, \\"The law is that if a non-Jew or a slave consorts with a daughter of Israel the child is legitimate.\\" Ostensibly, that definitive ruling represents an adjudication of the earlier controversy and the term \\"<i>kosher</i>\\" or \\"legitimate\\" is used as the antonym of \\"<i>mamzer</i>\\" or \\"bastard\\" with the implication that the child is legitimate but nevertheless forbidden to a <i>kohen</i> as had earlier been stated. Rosh understands the Gemara in that manner and rules that the daughter is certainly forbidden to a <i>kohen</i>.", "Rif, however, states that some authorities rule that the daughter is not only legitimate but permitted to a <i>kohen</i> as well. Presumably, the rationale underlying that position is that, since there is no halakhically recognized paternal-filial relationship between the biological father and the child, there is no basis for disqualifying her from marrying a <i>kohen</i>. The term <i>kosher</i> is understood by the authorities cited by Rif as \\"legitimate\\" in the fullest sense of the term and the dictum is understood by him, not as adjudication between two conflicting views, but as the expression of a third, previously unexpressed position, which is pronounced to be normative.", "Ramban, <i>Yevamot</i> 45a, similarly asserts that the Gemara records three distinct views with regard to the status of such progeny and, although the Gemara clearly rules that the child is not a <i>mamzer</i>, there is no definitive ruling with regard to whether a daughter of such a liaison may marry a <i>kohen</i>. Since the issue remains a matter of doubt, Ramban rules that such a girl may not enter into marriage with a <i>kohen</i> but, <i>post factum</i>, if such a marriage has been celebrated, they cannot be compelled to divorce.<sup>15</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Rambam\\u2019s position is a matter of some dispute. Rambam, <i>Hilkhot Issurei Bi\\u2019ah</i> 15:3, rules that the child is legitimate but makes no reference to the status of a daughter <i>vis-\\u00e0-vis</i> a <i>kohen</i>. Accordingly, <i>Maggid Mishneh</i>, <i>ad locum</i>, presumes that Rambam regards the daughter to be permitted to a <i>kohen</i>. However, <i>Mishneh le-Melekh</i>, <i>ad locum</i>, advances evidence indicating that Rambam maintains that she is forbidden to a <i>kohen</i>.</i> Ramban ascribes that view to Rif as well. The view that Rif regards the matter as remaining in doubt is supported by the published text of Rif.<sup>16</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Cf., however, <i>Nemukei Yosef</i>, <i>ad locum</i>, and R. Yechiel Ya\\u2019akov Weinberg, <i>Teshuvot Seridei Esh</i> (Jerusalem, 5726), III, no. 54, reprinted in <i>Teshuvot Seridei Esh</i> (Jerusalem, 5763), I, no. 72. For a comprehensive survey of the positions of early-day authorities regarding this issue see <i>idem</i>, <i>Teshuvot Seridei Esh</i> (Jerusalem, 5763), I, no. 71.</i>", "As previously noted, the prohibition against marriage of such a woman to a <i>kohen</i> is explicitly codified by <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i> in two places, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:5 and <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:19. Both <i>Helkat Me\\u1e25okek</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:3 and 7:26, and <i>Bet Shmu\'el</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:2 and 7:39, confirm Ramban\'s view in ruling that the daughter of such a liaison is forbidden to marry a <i>kohen</i> but, if already married, the couple need not be compelled to divorce.<sup>17</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\"><i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i> rules simply that such a marriage is forbidden but does not expressly address the <i>post factum</i> status of such a couple. R. Chaim Joseph David Azulai, <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i> 4:19, regards that omission as indicating that <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i> maintains that even after the fact they are forbidden to live together as man and wife. See also <i>Dibberot Eliyahu</i>, IV, no. 31. Cf., however, R. Shalom Mashash, <i>Shemesh u-Magen</i>, III, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i>, no. 58.</i> That ruling is explicitly accepted by R. Moshe Feinstein, <i>Iggerot Mosheh</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i>, I, no. 6. R. The issue of a <i>kohen</i> already living with the daughter of a Jewish mother and a non-Jewish father pursuant to civil marriage has been analyzed by R. Moshe Feinstein in his earlier-cited responsum<sup>18</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\"><i>Iggerot Mosheh</i> forbids marriage even in such circumstances. That ruling seems somewhat contradictory. The couple is forbidden to marry because of the possibility of transgression. The selfsame possibility of transgression persists within an already contracted marital union. If so, would not logical consistency lead to the conclusion that, if married, they must divorce? A number of latter-day authorities have endeavored to resolve that perplexity.", "One possible solution is that the prohibition is rabbinic in nature and the edict was not designed to apply <i>post factum</i>. However, the most cogent resolution is that advanced by <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>, <i>Hilkhot Issurei Bi\'ah</i> 15:3. A divorce executed under duress by a <i>bet din</i> is valid only if there are halakhic grounds for coercion. However, asserts <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>, if the transgression is doubtful, it follows that the grounds for coercion are also doubtful. If so, argues <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>, a <i>get</i> cannot be compelled in cases of doubt born of halakhic controversy because its validity would perforce be a matter of doubt with the result that the woman could not be permitted to remarry on the strength of such a <i>get</i>. Nevertheless, as a matter of religious law, the parties themselves are forbidden to continue to live together as man and wife. <i>Iggerot Mosheh</i> accepts <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>\'s explanation in ruling that a religious ceremony may not be performed for such a couple despite the fact that they have been living together in an ongoing relationship pursuant to civil marriage.<sup>19</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Cf., however, R. They considered the matter to be <i>post factum</i> because France, at the time, did not allow civil divorce and remarriage. Sanction of a marriage under such circumstances is certainly not consistent with the position of <i>Sha\\u2019ar ha-Melekh</i>.</i> <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>\'s resolution of the problem is particularly compelling if it is accepted that the prohibition is biblical in nature.", "Rabbi Mashash, on the other hand, in his previously cited responsum, was quite willing to permit marriage of such couples not only in situations in which a civil marriage had already taken place<sup>20</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See also Rabbi Mashash\\u2019s position in another case published in <i>Piskei Din shel ha-Rabbanut ha-Rashit le-Yerushalayim</i>, vol. However, if they have already married he is not obligated to execute a <i>get</i>. There is significant controversy with regard to whether, in such a situation, civil marriage constitutes a <i>post factum</i> condition. Those opinions have been analyzed in detail by this writer in <i>Contemporary Halakhic Problems</i>, I (New York, 1977), 286-290. Rabbi Mashash chooses to cite only the permissive opinions and entirely ignores the opposing position. He then summarily equates the case of a union between a <i>kohen</i> and the daughter of a non-Jew with that of a Jew suspected of having had a sexual relationship with a non-Jewish woman.", "Apart from the controversy with regard to the effect of civil marriage in the latter situation, according to <i>Sha\'ar ha-Melekh</i>\'s explanation of the rationale underlying that provision in the case of a <i>kohen</i>, the two situations are obviously entirely dissimilar.", "Rashi, <i>Yevamot</i> 24b, explains that the prohibition against a Jew marrying a convert with whom he is suspected of having had a liaison was promulgated in order to safeguard the honor and reputation of the husband since marriage under such circumstances is likely to lend credence to rumors of previous immorality. Accordingly, some authorities conclude that the prohibition does not extend to situations in which the couple have been living together publicly since in such cases previous immoral conduct is an established verity.<sup>22</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See this writer\\u2019s <i>Contemporary Halakhic Problems</i>, I (New York, 1977), 286, note 42.</i> <i>Teshuvot ha-Rashba</i>, I, no. 1,205, explains that, if the couple are suspected of having lived together previously, their marriage subsequent to conversion will lead to suspicion that the conversion itself was insincerely contrived for purposes of marriage. Accordingly, a number of authorities assert that, according to Rashba, if the couple have already established a permanent conjugal relationship, there can be no grounds for the suspicion that the conversion was insincerely entered into merely for the sake of marriage.<sup>23</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See <i>ibid</i>., p. 289.</i> Quite obviously, according to these lines of reasoning, in the case of a converted paramour, civil marriage or a longstanding conjugal relationship is not equated with a valid marriage as creating a <i>post factum</i> situation but is regarded as rendering the prohibition entirely nugatory.", "Rabbi Mashash asserts, again quite unequivocally, that in both instances the prohibition is rabbinic in nature and hence lenience is in order in matters of doubt. Indeed, if the prohibition is merely rabbinic and if, as Ramban maintains, the permissibility of such a marriage is a matter of doubt, it is difficult to understand why the marriage is not permitted even <i>ab initio</i>. R. Moshe Feinstein, <i>Iggerot Mosheh</i>, <i>Even ha-Ezer</i>, I, no. 5, depicts the prohibition as based upon doubt with regard to a biblical transgression. That issue has been discussed by this writer in <i>Contemporary Halakhic Problems</i>, IV (New York, 1995), 17-45. The theories offered in support of such authority are much more persuasive in matters of jurisprudence than in matters of religious law. The general rule \\"If a scholar has prohibited another scholar dare not permit\\" (<i>Berakhot</i> 63b, <i>Avodah Zarah</i> 77b, <i>Hullin</i> 44b and <i>Niddah</i> 20b) admits of exceptions in instances of clear error. It does, however, bar exercise of purely subjective discretion in choosing one set of precedents over another.", "It is difficult to believe that any objective scholar would find Rabbi Mashash\'s reasoning absolutely compelling. It is impossible to fault the <i>bet din</i> of Rehovot for assaying greater weight to the responsa of Rabbis Feinstein and Yosef than to those of Rabbis Mashash and Amar. It is quite easy to conclude that the lower court\'s decision was overruled simply because Rabbi Amar chose to follow his own previously announced opinion.", "Such a course of action might well be legitimate were Rabbi Amar able to allege a lack of cogency in the opposing view or to show that the weight of precedent contradicted the decision of the lower court. This he made no attempt to do. Mere preference for one set of precedents over another without a clear elucidation of doctrinal support is not the manner in which appellate review is carried out in the common law judicial system from which the Israeli system of rabbinic appellate review was adopted. Such a procedure strikes this writer as a misuse of appellate power.", "Furthermore, there is some question with regard to whether the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Rabbinical Court extends to \\"non-adversarial\\" matters. In an unpublished decision issued in 5702, Index no. 1/46/701, the Supreme Rabbinical Court held that it had appellate authority in all matters. However, in a subsequent unpublished decision issued in 5716 the Supreme Rabbinical Court ruled that it had no authority to hear appeals in \\"non-adversarial\\" matters, i.e., in determining issues of Jewish religious law since such matters are not within the ambit of authority granted to the <i>bet din</i> by virtue of the applicable Israeli civil law. The issue before the court involved the conversion of a minor child by its Jewish father in face of the announced opposition of its non-Jewish mother. The district court declared that it was not acting by virtue of the powers vested in a <i>bet din</i> to adjudicate disputes but was simply announcing a matter of religious law. The Supreme Rabbinical Court ruled that such matters are not subject to appeal.<sup>26</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See Eliav Shochetman, <i>Seder ha-Din (Civil Practice in Jewish Law)</i> (Jerusalem, 5748), p. 450.</i> The question of whether a daughter of a non-Jewish father is permitted to marry a <i>kohen</i> is similarly a non-adversarial issue of religious law.<sup>27</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">For a comprehensive discussion of the issues involved in determining the ambit of the appellate authority of the Supreme Rabbinical Court see this writer\\u2019s <i>Contemporary Halakhic Problems</i>, IV (New York, 1995), 17-45.</i>", "Moreover, as cogently demonstrated by <i>Iggerot Mosheh</i>, even in circumstances in which the couple will continue to cohabit even without benefit of marriage, celebration of a wedding ceremony is tantamount to rabbinic license to commit an even graver transgression. According to many early-day authorities, cohabitation outside of marriage constitutes a rabbinic infraction. Rambam, <i>Hilkhot Issurei Bi\'ah</i> 17:12, maintains that priestly conjugal prohibitions are biblically binding only within a marital relationship. Thus, according to Rambam, performance of a wedding ceremony transforms what would otherwise be a rabbinic infraction into a more serious biblical transgression.", "It is, however, not inconceivable that the same result might have been achieved on the basis of other considerations. As pointed out by Rabbi Feinstein in his earlier-cited responsum, in Jewish law, cohabitation for purposes of marriage creates a marital relationship when such is the intention of the parties. Whether or not such intention is presumed in a relationship tantamount to common law marriage depends upon whether the presumption that couples do not engage in fornication when the option of a marital union is available is applicable in situations of the nature described. An analysis of that very complex issue is beyond the scope of the present discussion. Suffice it to say that a <i>bet din</i>, in appropriate circumstances, might reasonably have concluded that the existence of a valid halakhic marriage necessitating a <i>get</i> for its dissolution was at least a matter of doubt. Since, in the case of a <i>kohen</i> married to the daughter of a non-Jew, a <i>get</i> cannot be compelled, it should follow that the recalcitrant parties may not be prevented from regularizing their relationship by means of a formal marriage.", "The verse \\"Speak unto the priests, the sons of Aaron and say unto them\\u2026.\\" (Leviticus 21: 1) serves as a prefatory comment to the prohibition against priestly defilement through contact with a corpse. The <i>Gemara</i>, <i>Yevamot</i> 114a, takes note of the double expression \\"speak\\" and \\"say unto them\\" in declaring that Moses was instructed to transmit two prohibitions: 1) a commandment addressed to adult priests forbidding them to defile themselves; and 2) a directive commanding adults not to defile young priests who have not yet attained the age of halakhic majority. The latter prohibition is recorded in <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 373:1. Rema adds that the prohibition is limited to the performance of an overt act on the part of an adult causing defilement of the minor. As explained by <i>Shakh</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 373:1, intervention to restrain a child from defiling himself is mandated only by virtue of a father\'s obligation with regard to <i>\\u1e25innukh</i>, i.e., \\"training,\\" and hence is limited to the child\'s father and, moreover, becomes applicable only at an appropriate age. The opinion of <i>Ba\\u1e25</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 373, to the effect that even an infant must be prevented from defiling himself is not accepted by other authorities. However, <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>Ora\\u1e25 Hayyim</i> 343:2, and <i>Mishnah Berurah</i> 343:3 emphasize that actively causing defilement is forbidden even in the case of a child completely lacking in reason.", "R. Eliezer ben Judah of Worms, <i>Sefer Rokea\\u1e25</i>, no. 366, declares that the pregnant wife of a <i>kohen</i> may enter a building in which a corpse is present by virtue of application of the principle of <i>sefek sefeika</i>, i.e., \\"double doubt.\\" There are two separate contingencies that would render defilement permissible, <i>viz.</i>, perhaps the pregnant woman will miscarry because the fetus she is gestating is not viable and, even if the fetus is viable, perhaps it is a female. There is no prohibition against defiling either a non-viable fetus or a daughter of a <i>kohen</i>. However, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> certainly maintains that, in principle, it is forbidden to defile a fetus. <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s ruling is confirmed by <i>Shakh</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 371:1.", "Although <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s position is accepted as normative, there are reasons for stringency on the part of the wife of a <i>kohen</i> in refraining from coming into contact with a corpse. R. Chaim Chizkiyahu Medini, <i>Sedei Hemed</i>, <i>ma\'arekhet ha-samakh</i>, sec. 71, cites a number of authorities who assert that, although it is permissible to rely upon a \\"double doubt,\\" it is nevertheless a meritorious act of piety not to do so.", "<i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s construction of this <i>sefek sefeika</i> is challenged by <i>Pri Megadim</i>, <i>Ora\\u1e25 Hayyim</i>, <i>Eshel Avraham</i> 343:2. <i>Tosafot</i>, <i>Ketubot</i> 9a, s.v. <i>ve-i ba\'it eima</i>, declare that a doubt resolved by virtue of the principle of <i>rov</i>, or majority, does not constitute a cognizable doubt at all. <i>Tosafot</i> opine that the occurrence of rape generally becomes known to the public. Hence, in a significant majority of all sexual acts that do not give rise to reports of rape, intercourse is willful. Accordingly, declare <i>Tosafot</i>, the contingency of rape cannot be deemed a matter of doubt for the purpose of constructing a <i>sefek sefeika</i>. Similarly, argues <i>Pri Megadim</i>, the majority of pregnancies result in viable neonates; hence the possibility of miscarriage should not constitute a doubt for purposes of generating a <i>sefek sefeika</i>.", "R. Moshe Sofer, <i>Teshuvot Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i>, no. 354, resolves that difficulty by pointing out that the principle of <i>rov</i> serves, in and of itself, to determine that in the majority of cases the woman commits no transgression in causing her fetus to be defiled. Fifty percent of all fetuses are female<sup>28</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">This is empirically imprecise. Historically, the ratio of male births to female births has been 106 to 100. In recent years there has been a decline in the proportion of male births in North America and Western Europe. Those declines, although statistically significant, are small, with the result that there remains a plurality of male births over female births. See, for example, P. Morcelli, P.M. Thouth, P. E. Serrari et al., \\u201cChanges in Human Sex Ratio,\\u201d <i>Lancet</i>, vol. 355, no. 9218 (May 24, 2000), pp. 1858-1863. However, since the number of miscarriages and stillbirths is far higher than 6%, <i>\\u1e24atam Sofer</i>\\u2019s crucial point, <i>viz.</i>, that in the majority of pregnancies the woman commits no transgression, is indeed valid.</i> while some fetuses are not viable. The result is that in any given pregnancy there is less than a fifty percent chance that defiling the fetus entails a forbidden act.<sup>29</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See also R. Joseph Babad, <i>Min\\u1e25at \\u1e24innukh</i>, no. 263.</i> Although <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> invokes the principle of <i>sefek sefeika</i> rather than <i>rov</i>, <i>Hatam Sofer</i> asserts that the principle involved is indeed that of <i>rov</i> and that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s nomenclature is merely unfelicitous. There are indeed two separate factors to be considered\\u2014and hence <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s use of the term <i>sefek sefeika</i>\\u2014the possibility of a female fetus and the possibility of a nonviable fetus; however the two factors combine not to generate a <i>sefek sefeika</i>, but to generate a <i>rov</i>.", "Acceptance of the thesis that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> is expressing the concept of <i>rov</i> rather than <i>sefek sefeika</i> yields yet another ramification. The putative practice of not relying upon a \\"double doubt\\" does not apply to not relying upon <i>rov</i>. <i>Hatam Sofer</i> himself, <i>Ora\\u1e25 Hayyim</i>, no. 83, forcefully comments, \\"He who commanded and admonished us with regard to the <i>treifah</i> is He who commanded us to rely upon <i>rov</i>.\\"<sup>30</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See also <i>Pit\\u1e25ei Teshuvah</i>, <i>Yoreh De\\u2019ah</i> 116:10 as well as R. Moses Luria, <i>Avnei Shoham</i>, <i>\\u1e24ullin</i> (Jerusalem, 5747), I, no.1.</i>", "<i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>Ora\\u1e25 Hayyim</i> 346:2, takes issue with the basic principle upon which <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s comment is based. As noted, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> assumes that it is forbidden to cause defilement not only to a minor but also to a fetus. <i>Magen Avraham</i> challenges that assumption on technical grounds. One of the principles governing defilement as recorded in the Mishnah, <i>Oholot</i> 5:4, is that a \\"swallowed\\" (<i>balu\'ah</i>) object can neither defile nor become defiled. Thus, for example, if a person swallows a metal ring and then enters a room in which a corpse is present, the ring is not subject to the regulations governing ritual impurity. The fetus, argues <i>Magen Avraham</i>, is \\"swallowed\\" within the mother\'s body and hence is not subject to defilement. If so, there is no reason why the pregnant wife of a <i>kohen</i> may not come into contact with a corpse.<sup>31</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\"><i>Pri Megadim</i> suggests that \\u201cswallowed\\u201d objects are subject to defilement by virtue of rabbinic decree. <i>Teshuvot \\u1e24atam Sofer</i>, <i>Yoreh De\\u2019ah</i>, no. 354, dismisses that contention with the observation that, assuming there is rabbinic defilement of that nature, such defilement is not necessarily prohibited even to the <i>kohen</i> just as, for example, there is no prohibition against a <i>kohen</i> defiling himself by contact with a metal object defiled by a corpse. There is certainly no evidence of a specific rabbinic decree forbidding <i>tum\\u2019ah balu\\u2019ah</i> to a <i>kohen</i>.</i>", "R. David ibn Zimra, <i>Teshuvot Radvaz</i>, I, no. 200, resolves the problem by postulating that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s concern was limited to situations involving a pregnant woman approaching term. In such situations there is reason to fear that labor may commence at any time and hence that the child\'s head may enter the birth canal in the early stages of parturition while the woman is yet under the same roof as the corpse. Since, for purposes of Jewish law, the child is considered to be \\"born\\" when the major portion of the forehead enters the birth canal, the child would no longer be deemed \\"swallowed\\" within the mother\'s abdomen and hence would become subject to defilement. A similar observation is made by <i>Netiv Hayyim</i> in a marginal comment on <i>Magen Avraham</i>, <i>ad locum</i>. According to those authorities, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> had no need to justify contact with a corpse on the part of a pregnant woman during earlier periods of gestation since the fetus will assuredly remain entirely within her body; the need for justification was limited to the final stage of pregnancy when there is reason to fear that the infant\'s head may emerge.", "R. Jacob Emden, <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i>, II, no. 177, advances a completely opposite interpretation of <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s position. <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i> contends that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s comment is designed to justify contact with a corpse only during early stages of pregnancy but that, according to <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>, the pregnant wife of a <i>kohen</i> is indeed forbidden contact with a corpse during the ninth month of pregnancy. As does <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i> dismisses the notion of <i>sefek sefeika</i> on the grounds that, since the majority of pregnancies do not result in either a miscarriage or stillbirth, the possibility of a non-viable fetus does not constitute a halakhically cognizable doubt. Hence contact with a corpse during the ninth month, when emergence of the forehead is a distinct possibility, is forbidden. <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>, he contends, was concerned with establishing the permissibility of such contact only during earlier stages of pregnancy.", "Such justification is necessary, argues <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i>, because, in order to obviate error and confusion, the Gemara, <i>Hullin</i> 72a, in a different context, extends the rules cogently applicable during the ninth month of pregnancy to earlier stages of pregnancy as well. Ostensibly, that consideration should also apply in the case of a pregnant wife of a <i>kohen</i>. Accordingly, explains <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i>, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> intended to explain that contact with a corpse is not prohibited during earlier stages of pregnancy lest the pregnant woman assume that such contact is permitted during the final stages of pregnancy as well. <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i> asserts that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> reasons that no such ban is applicable because of the remote nature of the concern, i.e., there is no actual concern in the earlier stages of pregnancy because the fetus\' head is unlikely to emerge from the uterus and, even were the woman to place herself in such a situation during the final stages of pregnancy, the fetus may be either female or nonviable. In effect, as does <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, albeit for a different reason, <i>She\'ilat Ya\'avez</i> understands <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> as declaring simply that the contingency that is the subject of concern is remote and hence not a matter of halakhic concern, but not as contending that the principle of <i>sefek sefeika</i> is technically applicable.", "R. Chaim Joseph David Azulai, <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, <i>Ora\\u1e25 Hayyim</i> 343:4, rejects the applicability of the principle of <i>tum\'ah balu\'ah</i> on the basis of the talmudic opinion, <i>Gittin</i> 23b, that maintains that the fetus is deemed to be an integral part of the mother\'s body (<i>ubbar yerekh imo</i>). As recorded by R. Jacob Ettlinger, <i>Teshuvot Binyan \\u1e92ion</i>, no. 96, R. Pinchas Shiffer, writing to Rabbi Ettlinger, explains that <i>Birkei Yosef</i>\'s contention is that the fetus cannot be considered to be \\"swallowed\\" since it is an integral part of the mother\'s body. Nevertheless, since the gender of the fetus is male rather than female, the fetus is subject to the rules governing defilement.", "<i>Binyan \\u1e92ion</i> dismissively rejects that understanding of <i>Birkei Yosef</i> on the grounds that to declare the fetus to be an integral part of the mother\'s body but to have the status of a male is a contradictory assertion. <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, in his previously cited responsum, without citing <i>Birkei Yosef</i>, reports that he had earlier considered the issue of <i>tum\'ah balu\'ah</i> as inapplicable, at least prior to commencement of labor, because of the principle <i>ubbar yerekh imo</i>. However, upon reflection, <i>Hatam Sofer</i> declares that he has reversed his earlier view because of the pronouncement of the Gemara, <i>Yevamot</i> 67a, that \\"a fetus in the womb of a non-<i>kohen</i> is a non-<i>kohen</i>,\\" i.e., priestly status, and hence the applicability of the prohibition against defilement, devolves upon the fetus only upon parturition.", "R. Moshe Sternbuch, <i>Teshuvot ve-Hanhagot</i>, I, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i>, no. 679, quotes the <i>Brisker Rav</i>, R. Yitzchak Ze\'ev Soloveitchik, as advancing an entirely opposite view in stating that a male fetus does indeed have the status of a <i>kohen</i>. The statement of the Gemara to the effect that the fetus is not a <i>kohen</i> is limited, he contends, to laws of <i>terumah</i>, <i>viz.</i>, although the mother of a <i>kohen</i> may partake of <i>terumah</i>, a women carrying a fetus who is a <i>kohen</i> may not partake of <i>terumah</i>. The fetal <i>kohen</i>, according to this analysis, enjoys the status of a <i>kohen</i>, particularly with regard to matters of defilement, but is not a <i>kohen</i> who can cause his mother to become eligible to partake of <i>terumah</i>.", "<i>Min\\u1e25at Hinnukh</i>, no. 263, espouses a diametrically opposed position in maintaining that even were the fetus to be regarded as rendering its mother eligible to partake of <i>terumah</i>, the fetus itself, since it is an integral part of the mother\'s body, is not subject to strictures concerning defilement.", "<i>Binyan \\u1e92ion</i> himself offers a novel interpretation of <i>Birkei Yosef</i>\'s position. The fetus, as an integral part of the mother\'s body, becomes defiled together with its mother. But since there is no prohibition against defilement of the mother, such defilement as part of the mother\'s body is entirely innocuous. However, defilement to which a fetus is subjected during pregnancy persists subsequent to parturition. Accordingly, contends <i>Binyan \\u1e92ion</i>, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> was concerned that upon birth it becomes retroactively clear that, in coming into contact with a corpse while pregnant, the mother caused prohibited future defilement of a <i>kohen</i>. Although no transgression is incurred until the fetus is actually separated from the mother, the earlier act causing future defilement of a <i>kohen</i> would be prohibited save for the principle of <i>sefek sefeika</i>.", "<i>Avnei Milu\'im</i> 82:1 dismisses the issue of <i>tum\'ah balu\'ah</i> by citing the rule that immersion of a pregnant woman for purposes of conversion <i>ipso facto</i> constitutes immersion of the child as well despite the fact that the mother\'s body serves as a <i>\\u1e25azizah</i>, or interposition, preventing the water of the <i>mikveh</i> from coming into direct contact with the child. The Gemara, <i>Yevamot</i> 88b, explains that the mother\'s body is not an interposition because \\"that is the way it grows\\" (<i>hainu reviteih</i>), i.e., only a foreign object constitutes an interposition whereas the mother\'s body in which the fetus gestates is hardly alien to the fetus.", "In effect, <i>Avnei Milu\'im</i> postulates that the reason a \\"swallowed\\" object is not subject to defilement is because the object in which it is encased serves as an interposition between the object and the source of defilement. The mother\'s body, however, does not constitute such an interposition.", "R. Samuel ha-Levi Woszner, <i>Teshuvot Shevet ha-Levi</i>, II, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i>, no. 25, challenges <i>Avnei Milu\'im</i>\'s equation of the principle of <i>tum\'ah balu\'ah</i> with the notion of interposition. The Mishnah, <i>Niddah</i> 43b, declares that a newborn child can become defiled through contact with a corpse. The Mishnah clearly excludes defilement of the fetus <i>in utero</i>. As explained by <i>Mishnah A\\u1e25aronah</i>, <i>ad locum</i>, the reason is that prior to parturition the fetus is \\"swallowed\\" within the womb and, accordingly, is not subject to defilement. Hence, <i>Magen Avraham</i>\'s puzzlement with regard to <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s comment is well-founded.", "R. Elchanan Wasserman, <i>Kovez Shi\'urim</i>, II, no. 41, resolves the problem in a highly original manner. Reb Elchanan maintains that a <i>kohen</i> is forbidden contact with a corpse even in circumstances in which he does not becomes defiled. In support of that thesis he cites the halakhic provision prohibiting a <i>kohen</i> from being in the same building as a <i>goses</i>, i.e., a moribund person, despite the fact that the <i>kohen</i> does not become defiled by virtue of his presence in that building. A fetal <i>kohen</i> \\"swallowed\\" in his mother\'s body, contends Reb Elchanan, is indeed in the same building as the corpse and is forbidden to be in that building even though he does not thereby become defiled.<sup>32</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Reb Elchanan clearly maintains that <i>tum\\u2019ah balu\\u2019ah</i> is not rooted in the concept of interposition, but is simply a divine edict.</i>", "At present, many obstetricians perform sonograms upon pregnant women for cogent medical reasons. Although performed for other purposes, such sonograms generally reveal the gender of the fetus. If the fetus is a male, and its gender is disclosed to the mother, <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>\'s <i>sefek sefeika</i> no longer exists since the fetus is known with virtual certainty to be male. Obviously, according to Radvaz, <i>Hatam Sofer</i> and <i>Netiv Yam</i> who assert that <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i> was concerned only with regard to a woman in labor or approaching term, there is no problem with regard to defilement during earlier stages of pregnancy. However, according to the authorities who regard a <i>sefek sefeika</i> to be necessary even during earlier stages of gestation, the wife of a <i>kohen</i> whose sonogram has revealed that she is carrying a male fetus would be forbidden to come into contact with a corpse other than in situations of <i>pikua\\u1e25 nefesh</i>.<sup>33</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Delivery itself, in this writer\\u2019s opinion, may take place in a hospital because parturition is categorized by Halakhah as a threat to the life of the mother and the danger, again in this writer\\u2019s opinion, is significantly mitigated by delivery in a hospital. See, for example, Jenny W.Y. Pang, James B. Heffelfinger, Greg J. Huang <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cOutcomes of Planned Home Births in Washington State: 1989-1996,\\u201d <i>Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 100, no. 2 (August, 2002), pp. 253-259. See also S.L. Barron, P. Blain, C.H.W. Bullough <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cCollaborative Survey of Perinatal Loss in Planned and Unplanned Home Births,\\u201d <i>British Medical Journal</i>, vol. 313, no. 7068 (November 23, 1996), pp. 1306-1309, and \\u201cDigests: Health of Mothers, Babies May Be Compromised in Planned Home Births,\\u201d <i>Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health</i>, vol. 34, no. 6 (December, 2002), pp. 320-321. This view is indeed disputed by some. See, for example, O. Olsen, \\u201cMeta-Analysis of the Safety of Home Birth,\\u201d <i>Birth</i>, vol. 24, no. 1 (March, 1997), pp. 4-14; Ursula Ackerman-Liebich, Thomas Voegeli, Katherin Gunter-Witt, \\u201cHome Versus Hospital Deliveries: Follow Up Study of Matching Pairs for Procedures and Outcome,\\u201d <i>British Medical Journal</i>, vol. 313, no. 7068 (November 23, 1996), pp. 1315-1318; and Kenneth C. Johnson and Betty-Annie Daviss \\u201cOutcomes of Planned Homebirths with Certified Professional Midwives: Large Prospective Study in North America,\\u201d <i>British Medical Journal</i>, vol. 330, no. 7505 (June 18, 2005), pp. 1416-1423. A patient suffering from a life-threatening condition\\u2014and labor and childbirth are categorized by Halakhah as life-threatening\\u2014may seek the ministration of a medical practitioner in whom he or she has greater confidence, despite attendant violation of religious law that would be incurred, even if an equally qualified practitioner might render the same care without such violation. See R. Joshua Neuwirth, <i>Shemirat Shabbat ke-Hilkhatah</i>, 2nd ed. (Jerusalem, 5739) 32:38.</i>", "The situation of a woman who has undergone a sonogram but who has not been informed of the fetus\' gender is somewhat different. To her, there is a <i>sefek sefeika</i> but one of those doubts might be resolved by means of a simple inquiry. <i>Pri Megadim</i>, <i>Siftei Kohen</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 110, <i>Kelalei Sefek Sefeika</i> 35:66, rules that when \\"mere inquiry\\" would resolve the doubt, it is obligatory to solicit such information. The crucial question, now that sonograms are available, and if they are to be regarded as posing no hazard to the health of either the mother or the fetus,<sup>34</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Basic research on harnessing the Doppler effect in the use of ultrasound waves for medical diagnostics was performed more than sixty years ago by the Viennese neurologist K.T. Dussik. See K. Dussik, \\u201c\\u00dcber die M\\u00f6glichkeit hochfrequente mechanische Schwingungen als diagnostiches Hilfsmittel zu verwerten,\\u201d <i>Zeitschrift f\\u00fcr de gesamte Neurologie und Psychiatrie</i>, vol. 174 (1942), pp. 153-168. As a result ultrasound became a primary exploration technique in obstetrics and gynecology and gained wide acceptance because of the absence of any known side-effects. See J.P. Schaaps, \\u201cL\\u2019Ethographie et la Gynecologie-Obstetrique: Du Bistable au 3D,\\u201d <i>Revue M\\u00e9dicale de Li\\u00e8ge</i>, vol. 54, no. 5 (2002), pp. 401-408; G.C. Mason, R.J. Lilford, J. Porter <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cRandomised Comparison of Routine Versus Highly Selective Use of Ultrasound in Low Risk Pregnancies,\\u201d <i>British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 100, no. 2 (February, 1993), pp.130-133; and J.S. Abramowicz, G. Kossoff, K. Marsal <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cSafety Statement, 2000 (reconfirmed 2003),\\u201d International Society of Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology (ISUOG), <i>Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 21, no. 1 (January, 2003), p. 100. Although four separate studies revealed an increase in left-handedness related to prenatal ultrasound exposure, that phenomenon has been dismissed as innocuous by some researchers. See K.A. Salveson, \\u201cUltrasound and Left-handedness: A Sinister Association?\\u201d <i>Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 19, no. 3 (March, 2002), pp. 217-221; and J.S. Abramowicz, G. Kossoff, G. Marsal <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cLiterature Review by the ISUOG Bioeffects and Safety Committee,\\u201d <i>Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 19, no. 3 (March, 2002), pp. 318-319. Others, however, have expressed concern that the phenomenon may be a sign of effect of ultrasound upon the brain. See H. Kieler, S. Cnattingius, B. Haglund <i>et al.</i>, \\u201cSinistrality\\u2014a Side-Effect of Prenatal Sonography: A Comparative Study of Young Men,\\u201d <i>Epidemiology</i>, vol. 12, no. 6 (November, 2001), pp. 618-623; and <i>idem</i>, \\u201cUltrasound and Adverse Effects,\\u201d <i>Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology</i>, vol. 20, no.1 (July, 2002), pp. 101-102.<br>In recent years the power outputs of clinical devices have increased with the result that the potential for both thermal and non-thermal insults has become greater. The risk of inducing thermal effects is greater in the second and third trimesters while sheer stresses from radiation pressure may be of concern in early gestation. The likelihood of producing undesired biological effects can be enhanced by new procedures such as use of gas encapsulated echocontrast agents. See S.B. Barnett and D. Maulik, \\u201cGuidelines and Recommendations for Safe Use of Doppler Ultrasound in Perinatal Applications,\\u201d <i>Journal of Maternal-Fetal Medicine</i>, vol. 10, no. 2 (April, 2001), pp. 75-84; M.C. One recent study concludes that the data available to date suggest that diagnostic ultrasound has no adverse effect on embryogenesis or fetal growth and that thermal effect probably does not influence fetal development but, while endorsing B and M mode during the first trimester, concludes that color, pulsed or power Doppler be performed with caution. See R. Hershkovitz, E. Sheiner and M. Mazor, \\u201cUltrasound in Obstetrics: A Review of Safety,\\u201d <i>European Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology and Reproductive Biology</i>, vol. 101, no. 1 (February 10, 2002), pp. 15-18. A number of researchers have advised that obstetrical ultrasound be undertaken only for medical reasons and that exposure should be kept as low as reasonably achievable. See, for example, S. Westin and L. S. Bakketeig, \\u201cUnnecessary Use of Ultrasound in Pregnancy Should be Avoided. Probably Safe, But New Evidence Suggests Caution,\\u201d <i>Scandinavian Journal of Primary Health Care</i>, vol. 21, no. 2 (June, 2003), pp. 65-67; S. Bly and M.C. Van den Hof, \\u201cObstetric Ultrasound Biological Effects and Safety,\\u201d <i>Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Canada</i>, vol. 27, no. 6 (June, 2005), pp. 572-580; and L. Morin and M.C. Van den Hof, \\u201cUltrasound Evaluation of First Trimester Pregnancy Complications,\\u201d <i>ibid.</i>, pp. 581-591.</i> is whether the pregnant wife of a <i>kohen</i> is obligated to undergo a sonogram before coming into contact with a corpse. <i>Shakh</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 110, <i>Kelalei Sefek Sefeika</i>, sec. 35:66, records two opinions with regard to whether a <i>sefek sefeika</i> may be relied upon in circumstances in which the \\"double doubt\\" may be dispelled on the basis of examination or investigation. <i>Shakh</i> rules that it is necessary to be stringent \\"when [it is] possible and no loss is incurred.\\" R. Shlomoh ha-Kohen of Vilna, <i>Teshuvot Binyan Shlomoh</i>, no. 13, similarly maintains that a <i>sefek sefeika</i> that may be resolved cannot be relied upon.<sup>35</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">See also <i>Sedei \\u1e24emed</i>, <i>ma\\u2019arekhet ha-samakh</i>, no. 29.</i> Nevertheless <i>Shakh</i> rules that no investigation is necessary if such investigation would entail expense. A sonogram, presumably, does entail such an expense.", "R. Ezekiel Landau, <i>Teshuvot Noda bi-Yehudah</i>, <i>Mahadura Kamma</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i>, no. 43 and no. 97, maintains that even the authorities who require resolution of the doubt posed by a <i>sefek sefeika</i> when such doubt can be resolved by inquiry or investigation do so only when both doubts can be resolved, but not if one of the doubts will persist even subsequent to the investigation. In the case of a pregnant woman, the doubt with regard to the viability of the fetus would indeed remain since it is not dispelled by means of a sonogram. However, according to <i>Hatam Sofer</i>\'s understanding of <i>Rokea\\u1e25</i>, since the vast majority of fetuses are viable, the operative consideration is not <i>sefek sefeika</i> but the consideration that the majority of fetuses are not viable males. According to <i>Hatam Sofer</i>, the principle actually relied upon is that of <i>rov</i>. The general rule is that a <i>rov</i> may be relied upon even when examination is possible except in instances in which there is a <i>mi\'ut ha-mazui</i>, i.e., a significant number of exceptions to the <i>rov</i>.<sup>36</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">For an explication of <i>mi\\u2019ut ha-ma\\u1e93ui</i> see chapter 7 of this volume, pp. 245-246.</i> The incidence of viable male fetuses is certainly a <i>mi\'ut ha-mazui</i> and, accordingly, examination for gender should be required according to <i>Hatam Sofer</i>. If the fetus is shown to be male, the principle of <i>rov</i> serves to establish that the overwhelming majority of fetuses are viable.", "Examination for a <i>mi\'ut ha-mazui</i> is required only when such examination is possible. Thus, for example, <i>Shul\\u1e25an Arukh</i>, <i>Yoreh De\'ah</i> 39:2 rules that a slaughtered animal whose lungs have been lost or misplaced prior to examination for adhesions<sup>37</sup><i class=\\"footnote\\">Examination of the lungs of a slaughtered animal is the paradigm for the requirement of examination in instances of a <i>mi\\u2019ut ha-ma\\u1e93ui</i>.
